section.title: Partitions and Counting
section.p: Two sets are called disjointsetdisjoint sets if their intersection is empty. A collection of sets is called pairwise disjointsetpairwise disjoint sets if every pair of distinct sets in the collection is disjoint. A partitionsetpartition of a set of a set S is a collection of pairwise disjoint nonempty subsets of S whose union is all of S.

statement.p:
Let S=\{a,b,c\}.
Write out all possible partitions of S.
Give an example of a collection of subsets of S whose union is all of S, but some two of which have nonempty intersection.
Give an example of a collection of subsets of S, any two of which have empty intersection, but whose union is not all of S.

proposition.title: Partitions from functions

statement.p:
Let f\colon S\to T be a function. (Do not assume that f is invertible!)
Show that \bigcup_{t\in T}f^{-1}(t) = S.
Suppose that t,t'\in T with t\neq t'. Show that f^{-1}(t)\cap f^{-1}(t')=\emptyset.
The previous two parts show that \mathcal{U}=\{f^{-1}(t)\colon t\in T\} is a collection of subsets of S whose union is all of S and any two of which have empty intersection. Does this guarantee that \mathcal{U} is a partition of S?

section.p:
A set is called finitesetfinite set if it contains a finite number of elements. A set that is not finite is called infinitesetinfinite set. The number of elements in a finite set S is called the size of S, denoted |S| |S|
size of a finite set S
. Formally, we say |S|=n, where n is a positive integer, if there exists a one-to-one correspondence \{1,2,\ldots,n\} \to S.

proposition.title: Counting elements in a set using partitions

statement.p: Let \mathcal{U} be a partition of a finite set S. We have |S| = \sum_{U\in \mathcal{U}} |U|.

corollary.title: Counting elements in a set using preimages

statement.p:
Let f\colon S\to T be a function, where S,t are finite sets. We have
|S|=\sum_{t\in T} |f^{-1}(t)|.

proof.p: Because every s in S is a preimage of its image f(s), we have s\in f^{-1}(\{f(s)\}). If t\neq f(s), we have s\not\in f^{-1}(t). It follows that every s in S is an element of exactly one of the preimage sets \{f^{-1}(t)\colon t\in T\}.

statement.p:
Let S be the 5-element set S=\{a,b,c,d,e\}. Given a partition \mathcal{U} of S, let \text{SIZE_LIST}(\mathcal{U}) be the list of sizes of the sets that are elements of \mathcal{U}, listed in descending order. For example, the partition \mathcal{U}=\{\{a,b\},\{c,d\},\{e\}\} has \text{SIZE_LIST}(\mathcal{U})=(2,2,1).
Find all possible size lists for partitions of S. (Hint: there are 7 in all.)
For each of the size lists in part a, give an example of a function f\colon S\to S for which the corresponding partition given by has that size list.

statement.p:
Let f\colon S\to T be a function, where S,T are finite sets. Use to show the following.
Suppose that f is injective. Show that |S|\leq |T|.
Suppose that f is surjective. Show that |S|\geq |T|.

ol.li: If f is injective, we have |f^{-1}(t)| is zero or one for all t\in T. Using , we have |S| = \sum_{t\in T} |f^{-1}(t)| \leq \sum_{t\in T} 1 = |T|.
If f is surjective, we have |f^{-1}(t)|\geq 1 for all t\in T. Using , we have |S| = \sum_{t\in T} |f^{-1}(t)| \geq \sum_{t\in T} 1 = |T|.

statement.p:
Let f\colon S\to T be a function, where S,T are finite sets.
Show that if f is injective and |S|=|T|, then f is surjective.
Show that if f is surjective and |S|=|T|, then f is injective.

ol.li: If f is injective, we have |f^{-1}(t)| is zero or one for all t\in T. Using , we have |S| = \sum_{t\in T} |f^{-1}(t)| \leq \sum_{t\in T} 1 = |T|. The only way that the sum \sum_{t\in T} |f^{-1}(t)| can be equal to \sum_{t\in T} 1 is for every preimage set f^{-1}(t) to have exactly one element, never zero elements. This means that if |S|=|T|, then f must be surjective.
